net.xeoh.plugins.base.impl

Class PluginManagerFactory

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.xeoh.plugins.base.impl.PluginManagerFactory

  • public class PluginManagerFactory
extends java.lang.Object
    Factory class to create new PluginManager. This is your entry and starting point for using JSPF. Create a new manager by calling one of the enclosed methods.

    There should be no need to access this class (or call any of its methods) more than once during the lifetime of your application.
    Author:
    Ralf Biedert

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static PluginManager createPluginManager()
      Creates a new PluginManager, no user configuration is used.
      static PluginManager createPluginManager(java.util.Properties initialProperties)
      Creates a new PluginManager with a supplied user configuration.
      static PluginManagerUtil createPluginManagerX()
      Creates a new PluginManager which will be wrapped in a PluginManagerUtil object, no user configuration is used.
      static PluginManagerUtil createPluginManagerX(java.util.Properties initialProperties)
      Creates a new PluginManager, wrapped in a PluginManagerUtil object, with a supplied user configuration.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        equals, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Method Detail

      • createPluginManager

        public static PluginManager createPluginManager()
        Creates a new PluginManager, no user configuration is used. The manager will be (almost) empty, i.e., containing no Plugins except some internal ones.

        The next thing you should probably do is adding your own plugins by calling addPluginsFrom().
        Returns:
        A fresh plugin manager.

      • createPluginManagerX

        public static PluginManagerUtil createPluginManagerX()
        Creates a new PluginManager which will be wrapped in a PluginManagerUtil object, no user configuration is used. The manager will be (almost) empty, i.e., containing no Plugins except some internal ones.

        The next thing you should probably do is adding your own plugins by calling addPluginsFrom().
        Returns:
        A freshly wrapped plugin manager.
        Since:
        1.0.3

      • createPluginManager

        public static PluginManager createPluginManager(java.util.Properties initialProperties)
        Creates a new PluginManager with a supplied user configuration. The user configuration can be obtained by using the PluginConfiguration.

        The next thing you should probably do is adding your own plugins by calling addPluginsFrom().

        In order to assist debugging, you can set one of JSPFProperties's preferences by calling: setProperty(PluginManager.class, "logging.level", "INFO") (INFO can be replaced by OFF, WARNING, INFO, FINE, FINER or FINEST respectively.
        Parameters:
        initialProperties - Initial properties to use.
        Returns:
        A fresh manager with the supplied configuration.

      • createPluginManagerX

        public static PluginManagerUtil createPluginManagerX(java.util.Properties initialProperties)
        Creates a new PluginManager, wrapped in a PluginManagerUtil object, with a supplied user configuration. The user configuration can be obtained by using the PluginConfiguration.

        The next thing you should probably do is adding your own plugins by calling addPluginsFrom().

        In order to assist debugging, you can set one of JSPFProperties's preferences by calling: setProperty(PluginManager.class, "logging.level", "INFO") (INFO can be replaced by OFF, WARNING, INFO, FINE, FINER or FINEST respectively.
        Parameters:
        initialProperties - Initial properties to use.
        Returns:
        A freshly wrapped manager with the supplied configuration.
        Since:
        1.0.3
